/Patrons of the dining room in
Levering Hall on the Johns Hopkins
University campus know Hamilton
Bishop, the waiter. Patrons of the
Levering lounge radio of Tuesday
nights, when a certain local talent
program is on, know Hamilton Bishop, the singing waiter.
Hamilton Bishop, who has a tremulous tenor and a lot of ambition,
hopes some day to be Hamilton Bishop, the singing ex-waiter.
He went to school with Cab Calloway, he said yesterday, and Duke
Ellington is a friend of the family,
but he hesitates to ask these two
popular Harlem entertainers for a
"break" for two reasons:
1—"I like sentimental songs and
slow music." Calloway and Ellington
seldom play sentimental songs and
slow music.
2—"I think my voice needs some
training, if I expect to get anywhere
as a professional entertainer."
"My friends have been after me
for some time to take singing lessons, but," he confessed, waiting for
a couple of orders to come up from
the kitchen, "my finances, among
other things, wouldn't allow it."
"Now, though, I'm getting two and

The waiter sang for a while at a

Dr Malone To Take
Degree From Emory

Rieke Speaks At Movie
Sponsored By Science Club
A movie entitled "Eyes of Science"
Will be presented at the regular meet1.ng of the Johns Hopkins Science
Club at the regular meeting tonight
at 8 P.M. in Room 1, Remsen Hall.
Dr. F. F. Rieke of the Physics
1)ePartment will give a short introdlictory address. The picture deals
With the construction and use of the
Inicroscope.
All interested students are invited
to attend this meeting.

Dr. Kemp Malone, professor of
En,glish,, at the Hopkins will receive
an honorary degree of doctor of letters from Emory University on December 12. The occasion for the presentation of this degree is the celebration
of the centennial convocation of the
university.
The procedure used in choosing Dr.
Malone as the recipient of the degree
was explained as starting with his
nomination jointly by the University
Council of Deans and the president
of Emory College, Harvey W. Cox.
This was confirmed by a vote of the
Board of Trustees.

Dr. William Kouwenhoven, Assistant Dean of the School of Engineering,
was the guest speaker at the Tau
Beta Pi Tap Day Exercises last Thursday, when the following engineering
students were pledged:
Rchard S. Strock, Walter O'Peale,
Samuel A. Rittenhouse, of the Senior
Class, and James Adams, William
Amey and John W. Chester of the
Junior class.
Choice of students for Tau Beta
Pi is based on Scholarship, personality
and breadth of interest, announced
Richard Schlotterbeck, President of
Tau Beta Pi, as he read off the names
of the students chosen.

Another scheduled feature will be

a badminton match between Reuben
Baer and Jimmy Benson, listed
"Baltimore's only two professional
badminton experts." Baer has often
denied this taint of professionalism,
but, nev ertheless, an interesting match
is bound to ensue when he and Benson
meet.
The main event of the evening will
be the Hopkins basketball team meeting the George Washington University
varsity "five". George Washington is
a member of the Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball Conference, noted for
being one of ine strongest leagues in
tne country. Th league includes such
powerful teams as Georgetown, West
Virginia, Pitt, and Temple. The capitol quintet is big, fast, and powerful
and should furnish a speedy, interesting game.

Musical Club Promises Varied
Program For Boarding
Students
Presenting its first concert of the
season, the Johns Hopkins Musical
Club, including the Glee Club, Banjo
Club, Hawaiian Troupe, Blue Jay
Orchestra, Quartet, and soloists, will
give a varied program at the dormitory tomorrow at 8 P.M. This is the
first time in the history of the organization that such a presentation has
been made.
There will be a dance immediately
following the concert, with the Blue
Jay Orchestra supplying the rhythm.
Both the concert and the dance will
be open only to the residents of the
dorms. Many private parties are being held prior to the musical program.

KKO Scout Coming
Mr. Willi, of RKO, expressed his interest in the Barnstormers and inquired into the possibility of attending
a rehearsal, because of previous arrangements to be in Baltimore before
the night of the show.
"Tickets for Once in a Lifetime have
been on sale at Levering Hall since
Thursday," said Bill McFeeley, business manager of the Barnstormers.
"Each student is entitled to a free
ticket on presentation of his S.A.C.
card. Otherwise admission price to the
play is one dollar. I urge all fraternities to make their reservations as soon
as possible."

Bubby Johnson and his well-known
colored orchestra, will be in the pit
at the Auditorium theatre to provide
music for the show. The band will also
play at the formal dance at Levering
Hall, after the play.
Prop Men Working Hard
Pete Checket, production manager
of the 'Stormers, reports that "we are
working feverishly to complete the
seven sets that make up the scenery of
the lavish play."
Properties, valued at more than a
thousands dollars, and ranging from
an expensive gold service set to several Russian wolf hounds have been acquired.
George Browning, critic of the
North Baltimore Home News, and
Donald Kirkley, Morning Sun critic,
have both recently commented on the

Barnstormer

satire.
They
were
equally enthusiastic in their praise.
"Once in a Lifetime is still the funniest play ever written about Hollywood," said Kirkley.
Misses Alice Tunatall and Olive
Bowman will act as sponsors of the
play.

Hullabaloo Photos Will
Be In P.O. Boxes Monday
All students who had their photos
taken the first time the photographer
was at the University will have a
chance to select the proof which they
consider best by Monday, Dec. 7, When
the four views of each student will
be placed in their post office boxes
Henry Kramer, Business Manager of
the Hullabaloo, said today.
These proofs must be returned by
Dec. 12, at the latest, or a fine of $1
will be charged if the pictures are to
appear in the yearbook.
The photographer's representative
will be in the Hullabaloo office from
Dec. 8 to Dec. 12 for the purpose of
receiving the proofs. Copies of these
may be had in small size at $2 per
dozen.

Mewshaw is a member of the engineering honor committee and of the
lacrosse and basketball teams. He is
running for the same position to
which he has already been elected
once. His opponent, Louis Swyer, a
Pi Lainda Phi, is a member of the
Barnstormers and opposed Mewshaw
in the invalid election.
In the struggle for the position of
secretary, the line-up Is a duplicate
of the final election last month. Finkel, who was victorious then, is a Phi
Sigma Delta, Associate Editor of the
NEws-LErrEa, a member of the Musical Club and the Barnstormens. Linkoff of Phi Alpha is on the business
staff of the NEws-LETTER.
Johnston In Race
The treasurership is being sought
by Johnston, Delta Phi, and Jarman,
a member of the track team. Johnston ran in the other election but was
bested by Clautice. Jarman did not
run before.
Thus far only Lachman, Phi Alpha
has been nominated for sergeant-atarms. He was the victorious candidate in the previous election.
The finals will be held today in the
Postoffice. Its completion will mark
the end of the election for this year
until the Student Council elections
in the spring.

'Cultural Olympics'
Willoughby Speaks Penn Faculty Idea

ToTudor And Stuart

The Tudor and Stuart Literary
Club feted Dr. Edwin Willoughby of
tlke Folger Shakespeare Library at
an informal smoker in its Gilman
Hall club rooms last Tuesday, December 1. Dr. Willoughby addressed the
group on "Everyday Readings in
Shakespeare's Time."
It was brought out in the talk that
everyday readings in the Elizabethan
era were mostly of a religious character. The Bible was then, as even today,
by far the best seller. Printers of the
Bible were allowed to publish any
number of books in one edition, while
ordinary publications were limited to
1250 copies per edition. In fact, so
important was this Bible printing,
that one might be brought before the
Star Chamber, prime judicial board,
for a printer's error of omission, as
one man was, for omitting a "not".
Sermons, and books useful in professions were second in popularity.
The reason for the popularity of
such works was that all work was
forbillen an Sunday, and people
turned to solemn treatises to fill the
day.

President Gates of the University of
Pennsylvania explained the new project more fully:
"In accordance with the first objective, an effort will be made to bring
the cultural olympics to the attention
of as many potential competitors as
possible by establishing contacts with
churches, schools, museums,institutes,
settlement houses, club, and other institutes and organization, which might
serve as helpful clearing houses for information concerning the project.
Second Purpose
"The second purpose—that of suitably rewarding conspicuous achievement on the part of participants—can
be accomplished best, it is felt, by
making the awards of such a character that they will not be of mere
passing significance but will serve as
vehicles for the further developments
of the cultural talents of their recipients.
"To this end it is hoped that provision may be made whereby a number
of these awards will carry with them
the privilege of study at various institutions which offer instruction in
cultural fields.

Rieke Speaks At Movie

A movie entitled "Eyes of Science"
Will be presented at the regular meet1.ng of the Johns Hopkins Science
Club at the regular meeting tonight
at 8 P.M. in Room 1, Remsen Hall.
Dr. F. F. Rieke of the Physics
1)ePartment will give a short introdlictory address. The picture deals
With the construction and use of the
Inicroscope.
All interested students are invited
to attend this meeting.

Dr. Kemp Malone, professor of
En,glish,, at the Hopkins will receive
an honorary degree of doctor of letters from Emory University on December 12. The occasion for the presentation of this degree is the celebration
of the centennial convocation of the
university.
The procedure used in choosing Dr.
Malone as the recipient of the degree
was explained as starting with his
nomination jointly by the University
Council of Deans and the president
of Emory College, Harvey W. Cox.
This was confirmed by a vote of the
Board of Trustees.

Dr. William Kouwenhoven, Assistant Dean of the School of Engineering,
was the guest speaker at the Tau
Beta Pi Tap Day Exercises last Thursday, when the following engineering
students were pledged:
Rchard S. Strock, Walter O'Peale,
Samuel A. Rittenhouse, of the Senior
Class, and James Adams, William
Amey and John W. Chester of the
Junior class.
Choice of students for Tau Beta
Pi is based on Scholarship, personality
and breadth of interest, announced
Richard Schlotterbeck, President of
Tau Beta Pi, as he read off the names
of the students chosen.

at the Auditorium theatre to provide
music for the show. The band will also
play at the formal dance at Levering
Hall, after the play.
Prop Men Working Hard
Pete Checket, production manager
of the 'Stormers, reports that "we are
working feverishly to complete the
seven sets that make up the scenery of
the lavish play."
Properties, valued at more than a
thousands dollars, and ranging from
an expensive gold service set to several Russian wolf hounds have been acquired.
George Browning, critic of the
North Baltimore Home News, and
Donald Kirkley, Morning Sun critic,
have both recently commented on the

Barnstormer

satire.
They
were
equally enthusiastic in their praise.
"Once in a Lifetime is still the funniest play ever written about Hollywood," said Kirkley.
Misses Alice Tunatall and Olive
Bowman will act as sponsors of the
play.

Hullabaloo Photos Will
Be In P.O. Boxes Monday
All students who had their photos
taken the first time the photographer
was at the University will have a
chance to select the proof which they
consider best by Monday, Dec. 7, When
the four views of each student will
be placed in their post office boxes
Henry Kramer, Business Manager of
the Hullabaloo, said today.
These proofs must be returned by
Dec. 12, at the latest, or a fine of $1
will be charged if the pictures are to
appear in the yearbook.
The photographer's representative
will be in the Hullabaloo office from
Dec. 8 to Dec. 12 for the purpose of
receiving the proofs. Copies of these
may be had in small size at $2 per
dozen.

Mewshaw is a member of the engineering honor committee and of the
lacrosse and basketball teams. He is
running for the same position to
which he has already been elected
once. His opponent, Louis Swyer, a
Pi Lainda Phi, is a member of the
Barnstormers and opposed Mewshaw
in the invalid election.
In the struggle for the position of
secretary, the line-up Is a duplicate
of the final election last month. Finkel, who was victorious then, is a Phi
Sigma Delta, Associate Editor of the
NEws-LErrEa, a member of the Musical Club and the Barnstormens. Linkoff of Phi Alpha is on the business
staff of the NEws-LETTER.
Johnston In Race
The treasurership is being sought
by Johnston, Delta Phi, and Jarman,
a member of the track team. Johnston ran in the other election but was
bested by Clautice. Jarman did not
run before.
Thus far only Lachman, Phi Alpha
has been nominated for sergeant-atarms. He was the victorious candidate in the previous election.
The finals will be held today in the
Postoffice. Its completion will mark
the end of the election for this year
until the Student Council elections
in the spring.

Willoughby Speaks Penn Faculty Idea

ToTudor And Stuart

The Tudor and Stuart Literary
Club feted Dr. Edwin Willoughby of
tlke Folger Shakespeare Library at
an informal smoker in its Gilman
Hall club rooms last Tuesday, December 1. Dr. Willoughby addressed the
group on "Everyday Readings in
Shakespeare's Time."
It was brought out in the talk that
everyday readings in the Elizabethan
era were mostly of a religious character. The Bible was then, as even today,
by far the best seller. Printers of the
Bible were allowed to publish any
number of books in one edition, while
ordinary publications were limited to
1250 copies per edition. In fact, so
important was this Bible printing,
that one might be brought before the
Star Chamber, prime judicial board,
for a printer's error of omission, as
one man was, for omitting a "not".
Sermons, and books useful in professions were second in popularity.
The reason for the popularity of
such works was that all work was
forbillen an Sunday, and people
turned to solemn treatises to fill the
day.

President Gates of the University of
Pennsylvania explained the new project more fully:
"In accordance with the first objective, an effort will be made to bring
the cultural olympics to the attention
of as many potential competitors as
possible by establishing contacts with
churches, schools, museums,institutes,
settlement houses, club, and other institutes and organization, which might
serve as helpful clearing houses for information concerning the project.
Second Purpose
"The second purpose—that of suitably rewarding conspicuous achievement on the part of participants—can
be accomplished best, it is felt, by
making the awards of such a character that they will not be of mere
passing significance but will serve as
vehicles for the further developments
of the cultural talents of their recipients.
"To this end it is hoped that provision may be made whereby a number
of these awards will carry with them
the privilege of study at various institutions which offer instruction in
cultural fields.
